metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network: eddy covariance system of Huazhaizi station, 2022
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Huazhaizi station eddy covariance system (EC) in the midstream reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2022. The site (100.3201° E, 38.7659° N) was located in the Zhangye City in Gansu Province. The elevation is 1731 m. The EC was installed at a height of 4.5 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500A) was 0.15 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1-3 (high quality), class 4-6 (good), class 7-8 (poor, better than gap filling data), class9 (rejected). In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 10% of the 30 min raw record. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. 
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What is an eddy covariance system and how is it used in data collection for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions?
Definition.Answer: An eddy covariance system is a key data collection method used to measure turbulent fluxes of energy, water vapor, and carbon in arid regions. It provides half-hourly data on these fluxes and is complemented by other instruments such as scintillometers for comprehensive observation.

Definition.Question: What are the primary challenges in collecting data related to ecological environment degradation in inland river basins of arid and semiarid areas?
Definition.Answer: The primary challenges include dealing with ecological crises such as drying rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms, which complicate data collection and require robust methodologies to capture accurate environmental data.

Comparison.Question: How do data collection methods using eddy covariance systems compare to those using scintillometers in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Comparison.Answer: Eddy covariance systems provide half-hourly turbulent flux data, which is crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. Scintillometers also contribute to this understanding, but the specific differences in data they provide are not detailed in the field description above.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the data processing techniques for eddy covariance data differ from those used for hydrometeorological data in oasis–desert studies?
Comparison.Answer: Eddy covariance data processing involves steps like coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and quality assessment, whereas hydrometeorological data involves processing for radiation, soil heat flux, and temperature profiles with a 10-minute average period. Both require careful data archiving and sharing procedures.

Comparison.Question: What are the main differences in challenges faced when collecting data in oasis–desert systems compared to other arid or semiarid regions?
Comparison.Answer: In oasis–desert systems, maintaining the balance between oasis and desert areas is critical due to their impact on ecological stability and socioeconomic development. Other arid regions face challenges like river and lake drying, vegetation degradation, and increased desertification, which may not be as pronounced or have the same socioeconomic impacts as in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Interpretation.Question: What are the main challenges faced in data collection in arid and semiarid inland river basins, and how can long-term observational datasets help address these challenges?
Interpretation.Answer: The main challenges in arid and semiarid inland river basins include ecological environment degradation, such as river and lake drying, natural vegetation degradation, land desertification, and dust storms. Long-term observational datasets, which include energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, help address these challenges by providing essential data for understanding and maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems, which is critical for sustainable development.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways do auxiliary data, such as hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, contribute to the robustness and applicability of datasets focused on oasis-desert areas?
Interpretation.Answer: Auxiliary data, such as hydrometeorological observations and vegetation and soil parameters, complement the primary flux data by providing additional context and insights into the environmental conditions affecting the oasis-desert systems. This comprehensive dataset structure enhances the robustness and applicability of the datasets, facilitating a more accurate and holistic understanding of the ecological and climatic interactions in these regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the selection of specific locations for installing eddy covariance systems in arid and semi-arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Locations for eddy covariance systems are typically selected based on the need to understand energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which are crucial for maintaining ecological stability and supporting sustainable development in these regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of integrating long-term observations from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems using eddy covariance systems on the understanding of energy and carbon exchanges?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating long-term observations from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems using eddy covariance systems can enhance the understanding of energy and carbon exchanges by providing quantitative insights into these exchanges in oasis–desert ecosystems. This understanding is crucial for achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals, supporting ecological security, and promoting sustainable development in these areas.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes might result from the inclusion of auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters in observational datasets for oasis–desert systems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The inclusion of auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters in observational datasets for oasis–desert systems can lead to more comprehensive datasets that offer a better understanding of the interactions between energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes. This comprehensive approach enhances the ability to assess the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to achieve a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and supporting ecological security and sustainable development of oases. This understanding is significant for achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals, as well as maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of implementing data quality control procedures in the collection of turbulent flux data in oasis–desert areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Implementing data quality control procedures is significant to ensure the reliability and accuracy of the collected turbulent flux data. This is crucial for supporting the ecological security and sustainable development of oasis–desert areas, as it provides a dependable basis for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, which are critical for achieving sustainable oasis development.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in processing data collected by an eddy covariance system to ensure quality and accuracy?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collected by an eddy covariance system is processed using Eddypro software. The main steps include outlier removal, delay time correction, coordinate rotation (secondary coordinate rotation), frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Additionally, the quality of each flux value is evaluated, with checks for atmospheric stability (Δst) and turbulence similarity characteristics (ITC). The processed data is then filtered by removing erroneous instrument data, data within 1 hour before and after precipitation, and data with more than 10% missing rate in the 10Hz raw data for each 30-minute segment.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are data from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems collected and managed to ensure comprehensive coverage of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes over long periods?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems are collected using a combination of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for turbulent flux data. Hydrometeorological data, including radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles, are observed from automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period. Groundwater table data and supplementary vegetation and soil parameters are also included. Data processing involves collection, processing, and archiving/sharing to ensure comprehensive coverage and quality control over extended periods.

Enablement.Question: What data processing techniques enable the transformation of raw eddy covariance data into usable flux measurements in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The data processing techniques include the use of Eddypro software to handle raw 10Hz data and convert it into 30-minute intervals. The steps involve despiking, time delay correction, double coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, sonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Quality assessment of the flux values is also conducted, focusing on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity tests.

Enablement.Question: What challenges are encountered in maintaining long-term observational datasets in arid inland river basins, and how are these conditions managed to ensure data quality?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include ecological environment degradation such as drying rivers, vegetation degradation, increased desertification, and dust storms. Data quality is managed through strict data filtering processes, including removing erroneous data, filtering based on precipitation events, and ensuring low data loss rates within each 30-minute interval. Additionally, data processing and archiving procedures are in place to maintain the integrity of the datasets.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collected from oasis–desert ecosystems be considered crucial for understanding carbon cycle dynamics in arid regions?
Expectation.Answer: Previous research has identified oasis–desert areas as carbon sinks, which can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these ecosystems is essential for achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals.

Expectation.Question: Why is it important to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems when collecting data for sustainable development research?
Expectation.Answer: Maintaining a balance is crucial because oases, which comprise less than 10% of the area in arid regions, support more than 90% of the population. The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity, which is essential for the sustainable development of these regions.

Expectation.Question: Why might researchers face challenges when collecting environmental data in inland river basins of arid and semiarid areas?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers may encounter ecological degradation challenges, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, natural vegetation degradation, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These issues are particularly prevalent in many inland river basins along the Silk Road, making data collection difficult.

Judgmental.Question: How effective are the current data collection methods in accurately capturing the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: The current data collection methods appear effective as they utilize advanced systems like the eddy covariance system and scintillometer for capturing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. These methods are complemented by hydrometeorological observations from automatic weather stations, ensuring comprehensive data capture.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges might arise in maintaining the quality and reliability of datasets in arid and semiarid regions, particularly considering the ecological issues identified?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in maintaining dataset quality in such regions include dealing with ecological degradation like drying rivers, land desertification, and dust storms. These conditions could impact data collection equipment and affect the consistency and reliability of the data.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could datasets be expanded or refined to better support sustainable development goals in oasis–desert areas?
Judgmental.Answer: Datasets could be expanded by incorporating long-term observations and additional auxiliary data such as detailed vegetation and soil parameters. Refining data processing techniques and ensuring robust quality control measures can also enhance dataset reliability, aiding sustainable development goals.
